1.11.25  6:09 pm   What does "ahead of its time" mean?

      it means the thing resembles things from many years later. it's only possible to accurately say this when you look back into the past. you can realize that this thing in the past is a super early version of something that everyone else caught onto later. but if you say it about something in the present then you're basically just guessing because you don't know what's gonna happen later

1.11.25  3:37 pm   Hello from San Francisco! Have you ever been here?

      no, but i've seen it a lot, and i have noticed the following things about it: the streets aren't called "street", or "road", or "ave", or anything. it's not "Post st", it's just "Post". Also i've noticed there are an abnormally high amount of street names with 4 letters. The other thing that is noticeable is they tried to build a street grid on extremely uneven terrain, which was arguably not a good idea. also it was the location of a skateboarding movie in the 70s with no plot

1.11.25  1:14 pm   i would like to ask a question

      that could be arranged

1.11.25  11:48 am   If light is the only thing that's constant every where in the universe, then why is it so prone to mistakes? Why is light affected by gravity so that we see eg. stars that are behind the sun in a different place than they actually are because of the sun's gravity? Why could we see the back of our head if we looked to the side at the event horizon of a black hole because the light particles orbit around the black hole? The back of my head clearly isn't where the light indicates it to be.

     light doesn't actually indicate where it is. you've just seen so much of it in normal earth circumstances that you've learned to use it to interpret where things are. If you go (or look) to somewhere far into another world with where different circumstances apply, you will have to re-learn how to interpret it

      The fact that the speed of light is constant makes it seem so divine, but does it have to be so weird then?

     i'm not sure, but the answer is usually even more divine than you expected

     Also, if you fell inside a black hole, nothing might happen to you for hours and you would see the entire universe compressed into a increasingly smaller circle in your vision, the rest of which is complete darkness. Do you really think the black hole just swallows you "away" from the rest of the world or where would you go??? It seems like a place outside of our universe and I'm fascinated and confused because maybe some of my "why" questions could still be answered through math. Maybe we lack a dimension in our awareness to understand all this, but yeah I wanted to share my thoughts and confusion

     it's hard to fully understand things so far away when we have literally never spent a day off earth

1.11.25  11:45 am   Do you find it important to have a "half understanding" of an art form so you can discover entirely new methods as to creating a piece?

     for me the only genuine understanding is the part i arrive at independently by myself

      I ask this because I have really wanted to compose many pieces of music, but I find myself easily overwhelmed and demotivated. I know how to read music and I myself can play a few instruments. I find myself so immersed into music and I generate melodies and sometimes even whole songs in my head. However, when I try to put it on paper, nothing comes out, which is weird because I can perfectly hear every detail of the music in my head but actually notating it gives me difficulty.

     probably the majority of musicians nowadays go straight to sound, without having any intermediary silent paper stage. the silent paper thing can be fun, but it's a specific thrill that does not need to be the default way, and probably is only possible if you have sufficient experiencing making audible music

     This is likely more common than I think, but that's not the main point I want to make. A common thing I tell myself is that "learning music theory will help me actually make something" and then at that point I have to wonder; how much theory should I actually know?

     it's like taste. how much taste theory do you need to know? wait what the heck is taste theory anyway

     I don't want to sound like any other artist, neither do I want to be trapped into one genre. Self expression is important in art, and I feel as if an arbitrary concept will hold back at that (especially with something as highly regarded as music "theory"). However, I also feel as if being completely clueless about it won't lead to any progress.

     it's like meeting a new person and falling in love with them. first it's important to buy and read a book that someone else wrote about how to fall in love with that person, in order to do it correctly. no i'm just kidding, this is not the case

     Is it possible to develop even your own personal theory?

     i personally am unable to understand any theory unless i've come up with it on my own. even if i know someone else may have found exactly the same thing before, it won't make any sense to me until i do it myself. This may be true for anyone, but i find it even more violently true for me than for others. i'm sure it has advantages and disadvantages

      I like emailing/asking questions to those I admire, and I thought taking this one to you would especially give me some sort of understanding. Have a great 2025!

     i was thinking of combining 2025 and 2026 together actually
